children.name: foreigner
children.definition: sb who comes from another country - many people consider itimpoliteto: người nước ngoài

children.name: A lot of foreigners work here illegally. Nhiều người ngoại quốc làm việc một cách bất hợp pháp
examples: Saleem felt that people were suspicious of him because he was a foreigner.
About 40 million foreigners visited the US last year.

children.name: Register
examples: The wordforeignercan sound negative and not very friendly. In everyday English, people often saypeople from other countries:
I like meetingpeople from other countries.

children.name: expatriate
children.definition: /expat sb who has gone to live in a foreign country, especially because theyhave a job there: người sống xa xứ
examples: I was in Spain for over a year, but most of my friends were expatriates.
Schmidt was a German expatriate who had been living in Portugal since 1989.
A largecommunity ofexpatriates has settled there.

children.name: alien
children.definition: sb who lives or works in your country, but who comes from another country - used especially in legal and official contexts: người nước, công dân ngoại quốc
examples: Some aliens may qualify for citizenship under the new law.

children.name: illegal alienscông dân bất hợp pháp
examples: The law makes it easier to find and deport illegal aliens.
illegal aliensentering the country.
Employers cannot hire illegal aliens.

children.name: kingdom
children.definition: a country ruled by a king or queen: vương quốc
examples: the United Kingdom
kingdom of
the kingdom of Thailand
the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

children.name: country
children.definition: an area of land that is controlled by its own government, president, king etc: quốc gia, đất nước
examples: Brazil is one of the biggest countries in the world.
The northeast of the country will experience heavy rainfall and high winds.
Most people in this country are worried about the economy.
all over/ all around the country
Riots and demonstrations broke out all over the country after the assassination of Martin Luther King.
a democratic/capitalist/communist etc countrythe former socialist countries of Eastern Europe
an industrialized countryAmerica and other industrialized countries
an advanced countrytechnologically advanced countries such as Japan

children.name: a foreign country
children.definition: not your own country
examples: Have you ever worked in a foreign country?

children.name: a strange country
children.definition: not your own country
examples: She was in a strange country, with no friends and no family.

children.name: a
examples: European/African/Asian etc countryThe President will be visiting four European countries.

children.name: your home/native country
children.definition: where you were born or live permanently
examples: After five years in America, she returned to her home country, Japan.

children.name: a developing/Third World country
children.definition: poor and trying to increase its industry and trade
examples: Many developing countries receive some foreign aid.

children.name: a developed country
children.definition: rich and where most people have a comfortable life
examples: Developed countries are responsible for most emissions of carbon dioxide.

children.name: an underdeveloped country
children.definition: poor and developing more slowly than others
examples: The disease still exists, mainly in underdeveloped countries.

children.name: a
examples: Christian/Muslim/Catholic etc countryEngland became a Christian country in the seventh century.

children.name: your adopted country
children.definition: that you have chosen to live in permanently
examples: I felt proud of my adopted country, America.

children.name: a great country
children.definition: important, with many past achievements
examples: the great countries of Europe

children.name: an independent country
children.definition: not controlled by another country
examples: Malaysia has been an independent country since 1963.

children.name: an occupied country
children.definition: controlled by an army from another country
examples: For many years, Egypt was an occupied country.

children.name: a free country
children.definition: where people’s actions are not too restricted
examples: You can go where you like – it’s a free country.

children.name: a member country
children.definition: belonging to a particular international organization
examples: the member countries of the European Community

children.name: the host country
children.definition: where an event is held
examples: Which is the host country for the next Olympic Games?

children.name: run/govern the country
children.definition: officially control a country
examples: The government has the job of running the country.

children.name: rule a country
children.definition: have complete control of a country
examples: For a long time the country was ruled by military dictators.

children.name: leave the country
examples: The journalists were given 24 hours to leave the country.

children.name: flee the country
children.definition: leave it very quickly to avoid trouble
examples: At the outbreak of the war, many people fled the country.

children.name: serve your country
children.definition: work for your country in an official way
examples: Remember those who are serving our country as soldiers, sailors, and airmen.

children.name: lead the country
examples: She became the first woman to lead the country.

children.name: represent your country
examples: It’s a great honour to be chosen to represent your country in a sport.

children.name: betray your country
children.definition: be disloyal, especially by giving secrets to other countries
examples: He betrayed his country for the sake of communism.

children.name: sb’s/sth’s country of origin
children.definition: where you were born or live permanently, or where something was produced
examples: Please give your name, age, and country of origin.

children.name: nation
children.definition: a country consideredespecially in relation to its people and its social and economic conditions and structures: quốc gia
examples: Japan has become one of the richest nations in the world.
Representatives from the world’s leading industrial nations will meet in Geneva.

children.name: a great/powerful nation
examples: The United States is the most powerful nation in the world.

children.name: an independent/sovereign nation
children.definition: one that rules itself, rather than being run by another country
examples: Countries that were once colonies of Britain are now independent nations.

children.name: an industrial/industrialized nation
examples: The rich industrial nations dominate the global economy.

children.name: a developed/advanced nation
children.definition: one that has many industries
examples: In the developed nations, many students go on to university.

children.name: a developing/emerging nation
children.definition: one that is starting to have more industry
examples: Food shortages are often a problem in developing nations.

children.name: a rich/wealthy nation
examples: Most tourists come from the wealthy nations of the world.

children.name: a poor nation
examples: The high cost of medicines in poor nations prevents many citizens from receiving health care.

children.name: lead a nation
examples: He led the nation out of a depression and into a period of growth and prosperity.

children.name: face a nation
examples: There are many problems facing our nation.

children.name: unite a nation
children.definition: make everyone in a country agree
examples: The crisis seemed to unite the nation.

children.name: divide a nation
children.definition: make people in a nation disagree
examples: The war has divided the nation.

children.name: shock a nation
children.definition: make everyone in a nation feel shocked
examples: This terrible crime has shocked the whole nation.

children.name: nation of
examples: We are a nation of both great wealth and terrible poverty.

children.name: state
children.definition: a country consideredespecially as a political unit that has a particular type of political organization: nhà nước
examples: In 1830, Greece became an independent state.
The state of Israel was created in 1948.
an independent state(alsoa sovereign stateformal)Croatia became an independent state in 1991.
a democratic stateThey wanted to transform the country into a modern democratic state.
a totalitarian state(= where there is no democracy )Politicians get away with this sort of behaviour only in totalitarian states.
a one-party stateUntil recently, the country was a one-party state.
a communist/socialist stateThe former communist states began opening up their markets to foreign investment.
a fascist stateFreedom of speech is not tolerated in a fascist state.
a police state(= where the government strictly controls what people can say or do )Too many laws bring us frighteningly close to the creation of a police state.
a member state(= a country that belongs to an organization of countries ) nước thành viên
The statement said that NATO would counter any attack against a member state.
the member states of the European Union
a NATOmember state(= a country belonging to NATO )

children.name: power
children.definition: a strong country that is able to influence other countries politically or economically: cường quốc
examples: The western powers hardly knew how to react to this threat.
France was the only European power not to sign the treaty.
The United States had replaced Great Britain as the dominant world power.
Germany’s strong industrial base has helped maintain its status as a major world power.

children.name: a great power
examples: Britain wanted to maintain her status as a great power.

children.name: a major power
children.definition: very important one
examples: There will be representatives from all the world's major powers at the conference.

children.name: a world power
children.definition: one with influence all over the world

children.name: a military/naval power
children.definition: with a very strong army or navy
examples: Russia had become a naval power equal to Spain.

children.name: a foreign power
examples: He was charged with spying for a foreign power.

children.name: superpower
children.definition: a nation that has very great military and political power: siêu cường quốc
examples: The book traces the emergence of China as a superpower in the 21st century.

children.name: land
children.definition: country - use this especially in stories and in formal speeches: vùng đất
examples: His travels in foreign lands provided him with the inspiration for many of his poems and songs.
Our story takes place in a far-off land, long, long ago.

children.name: He told them about his journeys to foreign lands.|a traveller from a far-off land
examples: Their journey took them to manyforeign lands.
Australia represented a realland of opportunityfor thousands of people.

children.name: native land(= the land where you were born )
examples: He’s fiercely proud of his native land.

children.name: land that belongs to a particular country
territory
children.definition: land that is owned or controlled by a particular country, ruler, or military force: lãnh thổ
examples: Ecevit campaigned in May 1991 to have foreign troops removed from Turkish territory.
Hong Kong became Chinese territory in 1997.
enemy/hostile territoryPatterson had never flown so deep into enemy territory before.
occupied territory(= land that is controlled by a foreign country or its army )America has always wanted Israel to give up some of the occupied territory.
disputed territory(= land that two countries are fighting or arguing to get control of )The latest round of talks over the disputed territory begins next week.
neutral territory(= a place or country that is not controlled by either of the groups or countries involved in a war )After crossing the frontier post, he would be safe in neutral territory.
Chinese/German etc territoryThe Russians handed over to Poland a large slice of German territory.
A committee has been set up to deal with territorial disputes in the area.
The country has suffered substantial territorial losses in this war.

children.name: territorial[attri adj] [
examples: C2] relating to land that is owned or controlled by a particular country or government:

children.name: on British/French/US etc soil
children.definition: on land that belongs to Britain, France, the US etc - use this to talk especially about important events: vùng đất, miền đất
examples: The treaty will be signed on US soil.
This was the first time that the Pope had set foot on Cuban soil.

children.name: all the people who live in a particular country
the people
children.definition: all the people of a country: người dân
examples: It was a fair election, the people have made their decision, and we must all accept it.

children.name: the American/British/Thai etc people
examples: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair said the British should stand shoulder to shoulder with the American people.

children.name: my/our peopleđồng bào ta
examples: ‘Millions of our people are still victims of poverty,’ said Mandela.

children.name: the people of
examples: To what extent did the people of Italy support the new government?

children.name: the country
children.definition: /the nation all the people of a country, considered together as a group - use this especially to talk about important events that affect everyone in the country: dân tộc, cả nước, nhân dân
examples: The President will make a radio broadcast to the nation this evening.
When Churchill died, the whole nation went into mourning.
The president seems to no longer care what the country thinks.
People think our country has lost its sense of purpose and direction.

children.name: citizen
children.definition: sb from a particular country,city or state,especially sb whohas the right to be protected by its law. công dân
examples: Noriko’s a Japanese citizen, but her parents are originally from South Korea.
Fahd became a British citizen after living there for several years.

children.name: a good citizen
examples: One of the aims of education is to produce good citizens.

children.name: a law-abiding citizen
children.definition: never breaking the law
examples: Most of the people in this town are law-abiding citizens.

children.name: a respectable/decent citizen
children.definition: good and honest
examples: There are gangs on the streets who are terrorizing respectable citizens.

children.name: an upstanding/upright citizen
children.definition: honest and responsible
examples: The rest of his family are honest upright citizens.

children.name: a model citizen
children.definition: a very good one
examples: His neighbours described him as a model citizen.

children.name: an ordinary citizen
children.definition: alsoa regular citizenUS
examples: The government is not aware of the views of ordinary citizens.

children.name: a senior citizen
children.definition: someone over 60 years old, or someone who has retired
examples: There are special clubs for senior citizens.

children.name: sb’s fellow citizens
children.definition: people who live in the same town, country etc as you
examples: 70% of our fellow citizens live in poverty.

children.name: a private citizen
children.definition: an ordinary citizen without a public position
examples: Laws exist to protect private citizens.

children.name: a leading/prominent citizen
children.definition: an important one
examples: The protests were led by leading citizens in the community.

children.name: citizen of
examples: Claire is now a citizen of the US.
The court’s ruling should be of interest to every citizen of Texas.

children.name: national
children.definition: sb who is a citizen of a particular country - use this about someone who is living in another country: kiều dân

children.name: Polish/ American etc nationalkiều bào Ba Lan/ Mỹ
examples: There are many Russian nationals living in Frankfurt.

children.name: foreign nationalkiều bào ngoại quốc
examples: During the war, foreign nationals were forced to leave the country.

children.name: a native of
children.definition: someone who was born in a particular country but moved to another country – used when describing a person or their life, especially a famous person: người gốc

children.name: a native of Spain/France/Scotland etc
examples: Picasso was a native of Spain, although he spent much of his life in France.

children.name: subject
children.definition: sbwho was born in a country that has a king or queen, and has a right to live there: dân, thần dân
examples: Northern Ireland citizens are British subjects.

children.name: a country that has a lot of power
world power
children.definition: a country that has a lot of economic and military power, and can influence what happens in other parts of the world:

children.name: cường quốc
examples: ▪ The United States had replaced Great Britain as the dominant world power.

children.name: Mỹ đươc thay thế bởi Anh như là một cường quốc
examples: ▪ China is regaining its place as a world power, a status it enjoyed for 3,000 years and lost only a few centuries ago.

children.name: Trung Quốc đang muốn có được vị thế cường quốc,tình trạng mà nó có đượctrong 3000 năm và chỉ mất vài thế kỉ này rồi
superpower
children.definition: uperpower  one of the most powerful countries in the world: cường quốc
examples: ▪ The United States, as the world’s only remaining superpower, must continue making arms control a central element of its foreign policy.

children.name: Mỹ vẫn giữ vị trí cường quốc thế giới, phảo tiếp tục làm trung tâm chính trị quốc tế
examples: ▪ He hinted at a bigger presence for the U.S. military in the Asian Pacific region where China is emerging as a superpower.

children.name: Anh ta ám chỉ sự hiện diện lớn hơn của quân đội Mỹ ở khu vực Thái Bình Dương nơi Trung Quốc là siêu cường quốc mới nổi
the legal right to live in a particular country
nationality
children.definition: the state of being legally a citizen of a particular country: quốc tịch
examples: The application form asks you to state your name, age, and nationality.
What nationality are you?

children.name: French/ German/ British etc nationality
examples: Despite being born in Germany, these children do not have an automatic right to German nationality.

children.name: dual nationalitynationality of two countries
examples: Jeanne has dual nationality because her mother is French and her father is English.

children.name: nationality of
examples: The nationalities of the plane crash victims have not yet been released.

children.name: has nationality
examples: ShehasBritish nationality.

children.name: citizenship
children.definition: the legal right to live in a country, use this especially when this right is given to sb who comes from another country: quốc tịch, quyền công dân
examples: After five years in the US, foreign nationals can apply for full US citizenship.

children.name: grant sb citizenshipofficially give sb citizenship
examples: Krebs was granted French citizenship in 1992.

children.name: French/US/Brazilian etc citizenship
examples: I have applied for French citizenship.
McGuirk holdsdual citizenship(= the legal right of being a citizen in two countries )in Ireland and the US.

children.name: the country where you were born
home country
children.definition: quê nhà
examples: Many of the refugees are keen to return to their home countries now that the fighting has stopped.
Jesper Parnevik became the first Swedish golfer to win a European Tour event in his home country.
After spending seven years in Japan, Claude returned to his home country of France.

children.name: native land
children.definition: the country where you were born: quê hương, tổ quốc
examples: Connery is a nationalist and fiercely proud of his native land.
Thousands of Irish families left their native land and went to America in search of a better life.

children.name: a country that is next to another one
neighbour
children.definition: /neighbor a country that is next to another one: nước láng giềng
examples: The relationship between Scotland and its southern neighbour has not always been peaceful.
Israel and its Arab neighbours.
